content.description: Sitting or standing start the climbs up and left.
Standing start that climbs through loose holds up the face.
This kickin' little line is more or less a standing start up the dihedral, with a fun throw to the last jug.

Social Security is a short yet powerful route.  

  It ascends the only obvious route on the South side of the Hobo Boulder.  

  Sit Start in the crevice/hole with a left hand on a pinch and a right high on a good jug. Very powerful and sequency moves on slopey ledges and crimps lead you to an enjoyable top-out. 

  Social Security is a very fun route which gives you a lot of bang for your buck.
content.location:
On the South side of the Hobo Boulder (the main boulder in the area).  

  It is Route 6 in the Urban Cragger. 

  The route starts in a little depression with a large boulder sticking out just to your right.

content.description: An array of sharp crimps up the face with good sit start variations.
Standing start on the crimps mid face, climb up and through without either arete.
Standing start, climb up the arete.
Sit start with hands on flake, follow cracks up and right.
Standing start with sit start variations.  Start left of rock, traverse right and climb up face.  Stay left of arete.
Start sittin with face holds in hand and climb up. (Starting lower under the boulder adds a lot.)
Sit start on the face holds left of the arete, then climb straight up the arete.
Start head first, descending into the hole climb towards road and finish with mangle back to where you started.
Sit start, climb face without the aretes.

This can be done as a sit start, or standing for the unambitious. Pretty straighforward; climb the bulge to a cool undercling, then to the somewhat creepy mantle without getting too much lichen on yourself. A key hold for me resides out left.
content.protection: Couple pads and a sober spotter, without whom a fall would result in rolling down the hill.
content.location: This tiny wall lies about 20 feet uphill from the Hobo Boulder. An open project is several feet to the right in a shallow dihedral. V10+ maybe?

content.description: Sit start on a low rail, climb out and up a face following the right arete.

This is an open project.  It has two polar opposite cruxes one right at the start and one near the end.  Start on crimps head height on the face.  Make a big dyno to a ledge, match and then gaston up and to the left, bump up your feet and dyno to the left arete.  Move up to a horizontal crack up and right then up to a crimpy flake.  Here rest the best you can before the second crux.  It involves using tiny crimps and slapping up the featureless smooth arete.  This leads to a couple of better crimps on the face before the top.
content.protection: TR for now, hopefully to be bolted soon.  A pad over the boulder to the left to protect any falls in the first crux, without it you might have a really sore butt!
content.location: On the face between Brewer's Arete and Brewer's Crack

content.description: Short but good crack climb in this (mostly) bouldering area...Belay from a dirty ledge and make sure to anchor the belayer.  Fingers to hands...   Despite being a short (but fun) climb, this is NOT a highball boulder problem as it starts on a ledge fifteen feet up and fall will deffinately ruin your day.
content.protection: Cams from finger to hand...4 pieces max and maybe a big hex to protect the belayer.  Sling boulders at top for anchor or build from gear.
content.location: The face above the boulders at Brewer's Park

content.description:
Climb the prominent arete to the right of Brewer's Crack.  All the business is at the bottom and then it mellows out to hard .11 climbing (at least that's what it looks like!)   This is an open project so if you are a D-Town hardman get on it, take pics and let us know if you send! 

  The crux is pulling to the second bolt without falling and hitting the ledge.  The first bolt just keeps you from cartwheeling down into the woods!
content.location: The prominent arete at Brewer's Park that can be seen from the road.

content.description: Start with left hand in seam, right on the lower crimp.  Move up right while climbing through shitty crimps.

climbs.name: All Brewed Up And No Where To Go

content.description: SDS on the right side of the blunt arete. Using hold on both sides of the arete work your way to a difficult top out.  Crux is the first and last moves.   Walk off/ climb off to the right (you may want a pad for this,you are basically down-climbing a chossy V1)
content.location: 75-100 yards east from Brewer's arete along the cliff line.

content.description: A collection of boulders and a small cliff band, this area holds quite a few good boulder problems and a couple of good roped climbs.  Better to go here early or late in the season to avoid the jungle and bugs.
